Run a complete RNASeq analysis workflow from counts to enriched genesets...

## Data import

```{r}
counts <- read.csv("GSE37704_featurecounts.csv", row.names=1)
metadata <- read.csv("GSE37704_metadata.csv")
```

## Data exploration

```{r}
head(counts, 3)
```

```{r}
head(metadata)
```

Check if the colData and countData match up

```{r}
metadata$id
```

```{r}
colnames(counts)
```

```{r}
#RM first column
countData <- counts[,-1]
```

Now check if the metadata and count data columns match
```{r}
all(colnames(countData) == metadata$id)
```

We need to remove all the zero count genes.

```{r}
head(countData)
```

To identify these zero count genes we can sum across the rows and check if the sum is more than zero

```{r}
to.keep.inds <- rowSums(countData) > 0
nonzero.counts <- countData[to.keep.inds,]
```

## DESeq setup and analysis

```{r}
#| message: false

library(DESeq2)
```

```{r}
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = nonzero.counts,
                              colData = metadata,
                              design = ~condition)
```

```{r}
dds <- DESeq(dds)
```


## Result extraction

```{r}
res <- results(dds)
head(res)
```
```{r}
summary(res)
```

## Volcano Plot


```{r}
plot(res$log2FoldChange, -log(res$padj))
```

Setup a wee color vector for this plot

```{r}
mycols <- rep("gray", nrow(res) )


mycols[ abs(res$log2FoldChange) > 2 ] <- "red"


inds <- (res$padj < 0.01) & (abs(res$log2FoldChange) > 2 )
mycols[ inds ] <- "blue"

plot( res$log2FoldChange, -log(res$padj),col=mycols, xlab="Log2(FoldChange)", ylab="-Log(P-value)" )
```


## Gene annotation

```{r}
library("AnnotationDbi")
library("org.Hs.eg.db")

columns(org.Hs.eg.db)
```
```{r}
res$symbol <- mapIds(x=org.Hs.eg.db,
                    keys=rownames(nonzero.counts), 
                    keytype="ENSEMBL",
                    column="SYMBOL")

res$entrez <- mapIds(x=org.Hs.eg.db,
                    keys=rownames(nonzero.counts), 
                    keytype="ENSEMBL",
                    column="ENTREZID")

res$name <- mapIds(x=org.Hs.eg.db,
                    keys=rownames(nonzero.counts), 
                    keytype="ENSEMBL",
                    column="GENENAME")


head(res)

```

## Pathway analysis

```{r}
#| message: false
library(gage)
library(gageData)
library(pathview)
```

```{r}
data(kegg.sets.hs)
data(sigmet.idx.hs)

kegg.sets.hs = kegg.sets.hs[sigmet.idx.hs]

head(kegg.sets.hs, 3)
```

```{r}
foldchanges = res$log2FoldChange
names(foldchanges) = res$entrez
head(foldchanges)
```

```{r}
# Get the results
keggres = gage(foldchanges, gsets=kegg.sets.hs)
attributes(keggres)
```

Now, let's look at one of these pathways: hsa04110
```{r}
pathview(gene.data=foldchanges, pathway.id="hsa04110")
```

```{r}
keggresids
```

## Gene Ontology

```{r}
gobpres <- gage(foldchanges, gsets=gobpsets, same.dir=TRUE)
```

## Reactome Analysis

We can use reactome via an R package or use their relatively new website interface. Let's use the latter.

It wants a list of our most interesting (i.e. significant) genes in gene SYMBOL format. 

```{r}
sig_genes <- res[res$padj <= 0.05 & !is.na(res$padj), "symbol"]
print(paste("Total number of significant genes:", length(sig_genes)))
```
```{r}
#sig_genes
```

We will write these our to a wee file so we can use them on the website:
```{r}
write.table(sig_genes, file="significant_genes.txt", row.names=FALSE, col.names=FALSE, quote=FALSE)
```

![Example figure from reactome online - mitosis](R-HSA-68886.png)
